facts.text: Respondent granted licence on August 18, 1954 under Imports and Exports Control Act, 1947 for import of fountain-pens not less than Rs. 25 C.I.F. value each from soft currency area, up to a defined amount.
Respondent placed order for Sheaffer pens from Australia; consignment received by air in Bombay in October 1954.
Imported fountain-pens had gold-plated nibs, caps and clips.
Customs authorities assessed duty under item 61(8) of Schedule to Indian Tariff Act, 1934 (articles plated with gold or silver) at 78 3/4 per cent ad valorem.
Respondent claimed goods fell under item 45(3) (fountain pens complete) at 30 per cent ad valorem.
Assistant Collector of Customs adjudicated duty under item 61(8).
Respondent appealed to Collector of Customs; levy upheld by order dated February 22, 1955.

Respondent filed writ petition in Bombay High Court for certiorari to quash higher duty and mandamus to release goods on payment of 30 per cent duty, without filing revision to Central Government under s.191 Sea Customs Act.
Tendolkar J. allowed writ petition on July 5, 1955, holding fountain-pens complete under item 45(3) at 30 per cent; interpretation not reasonably capable of contrary view; no lack of jurisdiction.
Collector of Customs appealed to Division Bench; Chagla CJ dismissed appeal on August 19, 1955, agreeing on merits but noting revision remedy time-barred by hearing date.
Central Board of Revenue issued ruling that fountain-pens with gold-plated nibs or caps fall under item 61(8).
Fountain-pens complete taken out of general item 45 (Stationery) by 1949 amendment; duty on stationery increased to 37.5% but fountain-pens remained at 30%.

legal_issues.text: Whether gold-plated fountain pens fall under item 45(3) (fountain pens complete, 30%) or item 61(8) (articles plated with gold or silver, 78 3/4%) of Schedule to Indian Tariff Act, 1934.
Whether High Court should entertain writ petition under Art. 226 without exhausting statutory remedy of revision to Central Government under s.191 Sea Customs Act.
Whether writ of mandamus proper to direct assessment under specific tariff item, given quasi-judicial nature of customs duty assessment.

petitioner_arguments.text: Existence of alternative remedy (revision under s.191 Sea Customs Act) bars writ under Art. 226 unless complete lack of jurisdiction or violation of natural justice.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 226 Constitution; precedents like Union of India v. T.R. Varma

petitioner_arguments.text: Customs authorities had jurisdiction to classify goods; error in classification within jurisdiction, not lack thereof.
Respondent's delay made revision time-barred by own fault; cannot claim discretion in favour.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: State of UP v. Mohammad Nooh

respondent_arguments.text: Imported goods are fountain-pens complete under item 45(3), not gold-plated articles under 61(8); gold-plating on essential parts like nib, cap, clip does not change character.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Item 45(3) Indian Tariff Act, 1934 Schedule; specific over general

court_reasoning.text: Agree with High Court: no reasonable construction places gold-plated fountain-pens outside item 45(3); nib, cap, clip essential; gold-plating for utility, common in pens >= Rs.25 CIF.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Fountain-pens treated as specialized class post-1949 amendment.

court_reasoning.text: Alternative remedy rule is discretionary, not jurisdictional bar; exceptions beyond lack of jurisdiction/natural justice; High Court discretion not improperly exercised given manifest error and departmental policy.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Levy at 78 3/4% manifestly erroneous; CBR ruling indicates settled policy.

court_reasoning.text: Sarkar J. dissent: Item 61(8) applies to all gold-plated articles except cutlery/surgical; 45(3) for fountain-pens simpliciter; no specific over general as neither overrules other completely.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Gold-plated fountain-pen is gold-plated article; harmonises schedule.

court_reasoning.text: Sarkar J.: Writ improper as assessment quasi-judicial, not ministerial; mandamus only to perform duty, not dictate outcome; certiorari requires error on face.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Duty to classify and levy is judicial per Sea Customs Act ss.29,31,32.

holdings.text: Gold-plated fountain-pens with plating for utility fall under item 45(3) at 30%; not 61(8).
High Court may exercise discretion to entertain Art.226 writ despite alternative remedy if not improperly exercised; here, no interference warranted.

precedents_cited.case_name: Union of India v. T. R. Varma
precedents_cited.relevance: Alternative remedy consideration for writ discretion.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rashid Ahmed v. Municipal Board, Kairana
precedents_cited.relevance: Adequate legal remedy taken into account for granting writs.

precedents_cited.case_name: S. Rashid and Son v. Income-tax Investigation Commission
precedents_cited.relevance: Alternative remedy does not oust jurisdiction but affects discretion.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh v. Mohammad Nooh
precedents_cited.relevance: Exhaustion of remedies is rule of policy/discretion, not law; exceptions where remedy lost by own fault.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gulabdas Co. v. Assistant Collector of Customs
precedents_cited.relevance: Classification error within jurisdiction; assessment quasi-judicial.

precedents_cited.case_name: Province of Bombay v. K. S. Advani
precedents_cited.relevance: Statutory authority acts quasi-judicially if required to act judicially affecting subject.

precedents_cited.case_name: Satyanarayan Laxminarayan Hegde v. Mallikarjun Bhavanappa Tirumale
precedents_cited.relevance: Certiorari does not re-examine as appeal; error on face required.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Tariff Act, 1934
statutes_cited.relevance: Classification of fountain-pens complete vs. gold-plated articles for duty rates.

statutes_cited.name: Sea Customs Act, 1878
statutes_cited.relevance: Procedure for assessment appeals/revisions; quasi-judicial hearing.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: High Court writ jurisdiction; discretion despite alternative remedies.

statutes_cited.name: Finance Act, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Increased duty on stationery but not fountain-pens.

outcome.summary: Appeal by Collector of Customs dismissed; High Court order upheld directing release of goods on payment of 30% duty under item 45(3); no improper exercise of discretion in entertaining writ.
outcome.relief_granted: Writ of mandamus confirmed; goods released on 30% duty.

key_quotes.text: "It is well-settled that when an alternative and equally efficacious remedy is open to a litigant, he should be required to pursue that remedy and not invoke the special jurisdiction of the High Court to issue a prerogative writ."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Principle on alternative remedies from Union of India v. T.R. Varma.

key_quotes.text: "The rule requiring the exhaustion of statutory remedies before the writ will be granted is a rule of policy, convenience and discretion rather than a rule of law."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From State of UP v. Mohammad Nooh; discretion key to writ grant.

key_quotes.text: "A fountain-pen may or may not be gold plated but a gold plated article can only be a gold plated article."
key_quotes.speaker: sarkar_j

key_quotes.text: "No reasonable person could, on the construction of the relevant items in the Schedule to the Tariff Act, hold that the consignment of fountain-pens could fall under any item other than 45(3)."
key_quotes.speaker: chagla_cj
